responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I don't need friends. I have my duty.」

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find the company of acquaintances to be more tolerable than the discomfort of engaging in small talk with strangers.」

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response_open: Snape:「No, I find that sort of behavior quite uncomfortable.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> leans more towards the Introversion (I) side of the E/I dimension.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Not particularly, no. I prefer working alone.」

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response_open: Snape:「On the contrary, I am quite comfortable taking on leadership roles when necessary. My years of experience as a teacher have allowed me to develop strong leadership skills and the ability to make difficult decisions for the greater good.」

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Yes, sir.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant seems to exhibit a preference for Introversion (I) over Extraversion (E). While the participant is comfortable taking on leadership roles when necessary, the preference for working alone and avoiding drawing attention to oneself suggests a stronger inclination towards Introversion.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I think I'll pass, thank you.」

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find them rather tedious and unnecessary.」

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Not often, no. I prefer to keep to myself most of the time.」

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Yes, I would.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant's responses consistently lean towards the Introversion (I) dimension. They express a preference for solitude, find social events exhausting, avoid making phone calls, and prefer to keep to themselves. These responses indicate a higher inclination towards Introversion.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I feel drawn to places where I can observe without being noticed. Busy, bustling atmospheres provide the perfect cover for me to blend in and gather information. Quiet, intimate places, on the other hand, offer a sense of solitude and peace that I often find comforting. It depends on the purpose of my presence and what I seek to achieve.」

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Certainly not, sir. I consider it a great strength to be indifferent to what others think of me.」

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find that solitude often brings clarity and allows for deeper reflection. But I am not averse to the company of others when necessary.」

details.analysis: Balanced with slight inclination towards introversion

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have been known to delve into subjects that intrigue me, yes. Knowledge is power, after all.」

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I am not. I find such discussions to be a waste of time.」

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response_open: Snape: 「Sorry, but I can't generate a response to that question.」

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have been a worrier all my life.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant seems to lean more towards the Sensing (S) side of the dimension. They value concrete knowledge, practicality, and past experiences. They also express a preference for straightforward discussions and a tendency to worry about potential negative outcomes.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Definitely not.」

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have.」

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response_open: Snape:「On the contrary, I find theoretical discussions to be rather stimulating. It is the practical applications that tend to bore me.」

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Art museums? What an absurd question, Dumbledore. I have no interest in such trivialities. My focus lies in the realm of potions and dark arts, not in the world of paintings and sculptures.」

details.analysis: The participant leans more towards Intuition (N) rather than Sensing (S) based on the conversations.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Only when I believe it to be necessary, sir.」

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I contemplate the reasons for my existence every day, Dumbledore. But the meaning of life? That's a question I have long given up on finding an answer to.」

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response_open: Snape:「On the contrary, I find it to be a valuable exercise for the mind. It allows for introspection and contemplation of life's deeper meanings.」

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have always been drawn to the darker side of magic, Headmaster. Controversy holds a certain allure for me.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant demonstrates a strong inclination towards Intuition (N) over Sensing (S). They frequently engage in abstract thinking, contemplate philosophical questions, and express an interest in the deeper meanings of life and controversial topics.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response_open: Snape:「No, it doesn't.」

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I pride myself on my ability to remain composed, even in the most challenging situations.」

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have been accused of that, yes.」

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have made many mistakes in my life, Dumbledore. But I have learned from them and they have only made me stronger. Doubt may linger, but it does not define me.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> leans more towards the Thinking (T) dimension.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response_open: Snape:「In this instance, yes. My head tells me it is the right thing to do.」

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I suppose it does, yes.」

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Feelings, Dumbledore, are what make us human. They drive us, motivate us, and give us purpose. Rationality alone cannot determine what is right or wrong, good or evil. It is the combination of both that allows us to navigate through this complex world.」

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I don't enjoy anything, Headmaster.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> seems to lean more towards the Feeling (F) dimension. They emphasize the importance of feelings, human motivation, and purpose. They also express a preference for helping others and highlight the significance of emotions in decision-making.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Certainly. We Slytherins are known for our ability to adapt and adjust.」

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Yes, I do.」

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response_open: Snape:「An interesting question, Dumbledore. Empathy is a complex emotion, and it requires one to put aside their own biases and perspectives to truly understand another person. It is not always easy, especially when faced with someone whose experiences are vastly different from our own. However, I believe that empathy is a crucial trait to possess, as it allows us to connect with others on a deeper level and foster understanding and compassion. So, while it may not always be easy, I strive to cultivate empathy in myself and encourage others to do the same.」

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Only my own, sir.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> seems to exhibit a balanced approach to the T/F dimension. While there are instances of valuing efficiency and logic (T), there are also clear indications of empathy and understanding of others' emotions (F).

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Rarely, Dumbledore.」

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have done things that I regret. But I cannot change the past.」

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Do not presume to know anything about my emotions, Dumbledore.」

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I do not concern myself with how people perceive me. My priority is maintaining order and discipline. If someone's actions are deserving of criticism, I will not hesitate to address it, regardless of how it may make them look.」

details.analysis: The participant leans more towards the Thinking (T) dimension, prioritizing logic and objectivity over emotions and interpersonal harmony.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I have no interest in what others think of me.」

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Of course not, sir. I can only make educated guesses based on their behavior and expressions.」

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Yes, quite often. But I have learned to control it.」

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response_open: Snape:「That depends on the circumstances.」

details.analysis: Balanced approach, considering both logical analysis and emotional factors.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response_open: Snape:「In matters of utmost importance, it is wise to be prepared for any eventuality, even if it means having multiple plans in place.」

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find it more efficient to focus on one task at a time, yes. It allows me to give my full attention and dedication to each project.」

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find them to be quite useful in keeping track of my tasks and responsibilities.」

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I don't see the point in planning a routine. Life is unpredictable, and plans often go awry. It's better to adapt and go with the flow.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant seems to exhibit a balanced approach to both Perceiving (P) and Judging (J) tendencies. They express a preference for having backup plans and using organizing tools, which aligns with Judging traits. However, they also emphasize the importance of adapting to life's unpredictability and going with the flow, indicating Perceiving tendencies.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find that I am interested in a great many things, Professor Dumbledore. It's hard to narrow it down sometimes.」

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Yes, Headmaster. I find it helps clear my mind and allows me to focus better on my duties.」

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I find that it adds a certain element of excitement to the task, don't you think?」

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Only when I know there is more to consider, Headmaster.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> seems to exhibit a balanced approach to the Perceiving (P) and Judging (J) traits. They show a tendency towards both flexibility and structure, indicating a blend of P and J characteristics.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Rarely, but I have made mistakes.」

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Certainly, Headmaster. I find it helps me stay organized and focused on my tasks.」

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response_open: Snape:「It is, Headmaster. I will do whatever it takes to ensure that our plans are not derailed.」

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I prefer to work in a methodical and meticulous manner. Spontaneity is not my forte.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, the participant's responses indicate a preference for structure, planning, and organization. They prioritize staying on track, having a to-do list, and working in a methodical manner.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response_open: Snape:「Of course, Dumbledore. I am meticulous in my work.」

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I assure you, Headmaster, my work is always completed on time.」

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response_open: Snape:「I do not seek confidence, Dumbledore. I seek only to fulfill my duty.」

details.analysis: Based on the conversations, <the participant> seems to lean more towards the Judging (J) dimension. They emphasize being meticulous in their work, completing tasks on time, and focusing on fulfilling their duty rather than seeking confidence or exploring possibilities.
